Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 3-day history of acutely worsened shortness of breath. She reports a baseline of chronic dyspnoea on exertion for the past 5 years, which she attributes to 'getting older'. This chronic breathlessness was initially noticeable after climbing two flights of stairs, but has gradually progressed to occurring after one flight or walking approximately 100 meters on a flat surface. The recent acute exacerbation means she now feels breathless even with minimal activities like dressing. She cannot identify a specific trigger for this acute worsening, though she mentions feeling 'a bit under the weather' with mild fatigue about a week ago, similar to a very mild cold, but denies fever, sore throat, or significant cough at that time. Her main concern is the increased difficulty in breathing with minimal effort.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Acutely worsened dyspnoea on minimal exertion, superimposed on chronic exertional dyspnoea
Secondary_Symptoms: Occasional dry cough, non-productive, mainly in mornings
Slightly reduced appetite over the past few days

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension (diagnosed 15 years ago). Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (diagnosed 10 years ago). Osteoarthritis affecting both knees. Cholecystectomy 20 years ago. No history of ischaemic heart disease, heart failure, asthma, COPD, or venous thromboembolism.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Retired primary school teacher, lives alone in a bungalow. Smoked approximately 5 cigarettes per day for 10 years, quit 40 years ago. Consumes alcohol rarely (1-2 units per month). Describes her lifestyle as largely sedentary, spending most of her day reading or watching television, with limited outdoor activity primarily due to knee pain and general tiredness.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Ramipril 5mg once daily, Metformin 500mg twice daily. Occasional paracetamol for knee pain.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies chest pain, tightness, or palpitations. Denies orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. No wheezing reported. No hemoptysis. No fever, chills, or night sweats. No significant unintentional weight loss. Denies recent long-distance travel, surgery, or prolonged immobilization. No calf swelling, pain, or redness. Denies syncope or pre-syncope. No urinary or bowel changes.

Vital_Signs.Respiratory_Rate: 20 breaths/min at rest, increasing to 26 breaths/min with minimal exertion (e.g., moving from chair to examination couch)
Vital_Signs.Oxygen_Saturation: 94% on room air at rest, drops to 90% after walking 10 meters in the examination room

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert and oriented. Appears comfortable at rest but becomes visibly breathless and uses pursed lips slightly when asked to move or speak at length. Body Mass Index estimated at 28 kg/m².

Cardiovascular_Examination.Inspection: No visible cyanosis or pallor. Jugular Venous Pressure not elevated.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Palpation: Apex beat not displaced, normal character. No heaves or thrills.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Auscultation: S1 and S2 heart sounds normal. No murmurs, gallops (S3/S4), or rubs. Carotid pulses normal volume, no bruits.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Chest shape symmetrical. No gross deformities. Respiratory effort appears slightly increased with minimal activity, but no use of accessory muscles at rest.
Respiratory_Examination.Palpation: Trachea central. Chest expansion slightly reduced bilaterally but symmetrical. Tactile fremitus normal.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Breath sounds vesicular and clear in most areas. Faint, fine bibasilar crackles noted initially, which cleared significantly after asking the patient to take a few deep breaths and cough. No wheezes or rhonchi.

Abdominal_Examination.Inspection: Abdomen flat, no scars apart from old cholecystectomy scar.
Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Soft, non-tender. No organomegaly. No masses palpated.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Peripheral_Vascular_Examination: No peripheral edema in lower limbs. Peripheral pulses (dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial) palpable bilaterally, 2+. No signs of DVT.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Musculoskeletal_Examination: Mild crepitus on passive movement of both knees, with slightly reduced range of motion. General muscle bulk appears slightly reduced in the lower limbs. Difficulty rising from a chair without using arms.

Coagulation.D_dimer: 600 ng/mL FEU (Laboratory reference <500 ng/mL; age-adjusted cut-off for 78 years approx. 780 ng/mL)

ECG.Intervals: PR, QRS, QT intervals within normal limits
ECG.ST_T_waves: No acute ST segment elevation or depression. Minor non-specific T wave flattening in lateral leads. Voltage criteria for LVH met.

Chest_X_Ray (PA_and_Lateral).Findings: Lungs are clear of focal consolidation, pleural effusion, or pneumothorax. Cardiothoracic ratio is within normal limits (approximately 0.48). Mild unfolding of the aorta. Subtle linear opacities at both lung bases, suggestive of minor bibasilar atelectasis. No overt signs of pulmonary edema.

CT_Pulmonary_Angiogram (CTPA).Reason_for_test: Performed due to acute worsening of dyspnoea and D-dimer being above the standard laboratory cut-off, despite being below age-adjusted threshold, to definitively rule out pulmonary embolism given clinical presentation.
CT_Pulmonary_Angiogram (CTPA).Findings: No evidence of pulmonary embolism in the main, lobar, or segmental pulmonary arteries. Lung parenchyma clear of consolidation or significant infiltrates; persistent mild bibasilar atelectasis noted. No pleural effusions. Heart size normal. No mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. Incidental finding of mild coronary artery calcification. Aorta mildly ectatic.

Pulmonary_Function_Tests (Spirometry).Post_Bronchodilator_Response: No significant improvement (<10% change in FEV1 or FVC)
Pulmonary_Function_Tests (Spirometry).Interpretation: Mild reduction in FVC with preserved FEV1/FVC ratio, suggestive of a mild restrictive pattern or suboptimal effort. No evidence of obstructive airways disease.

Echocardiogram_Transthoracic.Reason_for_test: To assess cardiac structure and function given chronic dyspnoea, hypertension, and to exclude cardiac cause for acute worsening.
Echocardiogram_Transthoracic.Findings: Left ventricular size and overall systolic function are normal (LVEF estimated 60-65%). Evidence of Grade 1 diastolic dysfunction (impaired relaxation). Right ventricular size and systolic function are normal. No significant valvular abnormalities; mild mitral and tricuspid regurgitation. Estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure is normal (25 mmHg). No pericardial effusion.

Six_Minute_Walk_Test (6MWT).Reason_for_Stopping: Patient reported significant dyspnoea (Borg scale 7/10) and leg fatigue.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Ageing and Lack of Fitness (Deconditioning) causing chronic dyspnoea, with acute worsening likely secondary to minimal exertion exceeding physiological reserve, possibly compounded by recent resolved minor viral illness or gradual decline in functional capacity.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 5-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath, which has become acute in the last 24 hours. She describes a background of mild, intermittent dyspnoea on significant exertion for the past year, attributed to being 'out of shape', for which she has not sought medical advice. The current episode began with what she thought was a 'cold' – dry cough, fatigue, and generalized muscle aches. Over the past 2 days, the cough has become more persistent, and she feels increasingly breathless even at rest. She denies any recent travel abroad but mentions visiting a local farmers' market with live poultry stalls about 10 days ago, though she denies direct contact with birds. She initially felt a bit feverish but hasn't checked her temperature.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Dyspnoea (acute worsening on a background of mild chronic exertional dyspnoea)

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Mild intermittent asthma, diagnosed in childhood, uses salbutamol inhaler very rarely (less than once a month). Hypertension, managed with amlodipine. No history of heart disease, DVT/PE, or other chronic lung conditions. No recent surgeries.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as an accountant. Non-smoker. Occasional alcohol (1-2 glasses of wine per week). Lives with her husband and two cats. Denies illicit drug use. Recently started a new gardening hobby involving handling commercial compost.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Amlodipine 5mg daily. Salbutamol inhaler (rarely used).
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Reports headache for the past 2 days. Denies chest pain, palpitations, orthopnoea, or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. No wheezing reported by patient. Appetite reduced. One episode of loose stool yesterday, but no significant diarrhea or vomiting. No skin rash, joint swelling, or urinary symptoms. Denies hemoptysis. Denies recent sick contacts at home or work, apart from general 'colds going around'.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert, appears tired and in moderate respiratory distress, using accessory muscles to breathe. Able to speak in short sentences.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Symmetrical chest expansion, visible use of accessory muscles.
Respiratory_Examination.Palpation: Trachea central. Tactile fremitus normal bilaterally.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Reduced air entry at both bases. Scattered bilateral fine crackles, predominantly bibasilar. No wheezes or rhonchi. No pleural rub.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Tachycardic, regular rhythm. S1 and S2 normal. No murmurs, gallops, or pericardial rub. Jugular Venous Pressure not elevated. No peripheral edema.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Bowel sounds present and normal. No hepatosplenomegaly.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Neurological_Examination: Alert and oriented to person, place, and time. No focal neurological deficits. Cranial nerves intact.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Skin_Examination: Warm and dry. No rashes or lesions. No cyanosis noted.

Sputum_Analysis.Gram_Stain: Few epithelial cells, mixed flora, no predominant organism, few WBCs

Chest_X_Ray_PA_and_Lateral.Findings: Bilateral hazy opacities and interstitial markings, more pronounced in the lower lung zones. No clear lobar consolidation. Heart size normal. No significant pleural effusions.

CT_Pulmonary_Angiogram_CTPA.Findings: Ordered due to elevated D-dimer and hypoxia. No evidence of pulmonary embolism. Diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities and areas of patchy consolidation, particularly in the dependent portions of the lungs. No significant lymphadenopathy. Pleural spaces clear.

ECG.Findings: Sinus tachycardia at 110 bpm. No acute ST-T wave changes suggestive of ischemia. Normal intervals.

Microbiology_Special_Tests.Rapid_Influenza_Diagnostic_Test_A_and_B_: Negative for Influenza A and Influenza B

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Infection: Avian Influenza (H5)

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a several-month history of gradually worsening breathlessness. She reports feeling easily winded with moderate exertion, such as climbing a flight of stairs, an activity she previously managed without difficulty. Over the past month, she has experienced two distinct episodes of acute chest tightness and an inability to 'catch her breath,' each lasting approximately 30-60 minutes. One such episode woke her from sleep. She describes these acute sensations more as a 'heavy feeling' in her chest rather than sharp pain. She also notes an intermittent, mostly dry cough, which tends to be more troublesome at night. She has observed that her breathing symptoms seem to exacerbate when she is cleaning her dusty attic or during high pollen seasons, and also following a recent upper respiratory tract infection.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Gradual onset of chronic exertional dyspnoea with recent acute exacerbations of breathlessness and chest tightness
Secondary_Symptoms: Intermittent dry cough, worse at night
Sensation of chest tightness during acute episodes
Increased breathlessness with exposure to dust and pollen
Worsening of symptoms after a recent URI

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Diagnosed with 'allergic rhinitis' approximately 10 years ago, occasionally uses over-the-counter antihistamines. History of 'recurrent chest infections' during childhood that 'took a long time to resolve,' no formal asthma diagnosis. No known history of cardiac disease, COPD, thromboembolic disease, or other chronic respiratory conditions. No previous surgeries. No known drug allergies.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a librarian. Non-smoker, denies vaping or illicit drug use. Consumes alcohol socially, 1-2 glasses of wine per week. Lives in an older house, built in the 1950s. Husband smokes cigarettes, but states he only does so outdoors. No pets in the household. Denies specific known occupational dust or chemical exposures at the library.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Patient confirms primary symptoms of dyspnoea and cough. Denies fever, chills, significant weight loss, or night sweats. Denies orthopnoea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, palpitations, syncope, or peripheral edema. Denies frank hemoptysis. Denies symptoms of GERD such as heartburn or acid regurgitation. No current joint pains or skin rashes.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert and oriented, appears comfortable at rest. No acute distress noted during examination.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Chest wall movement symmetrical. No visible use of accessory muscles at rest. Anteroposterior diameter normal.

Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Mild, scattered expiratory wheezes heard bilaterally, more prominent on forced expiration. Air entry is good throughout both lungs, but expiratory phase sounds slightly prolonged. No crackles, rales, or pleural rubs.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Inspection: No visible jugular venous distension (JVP estimated at 6 cm). No visible precordial activity abnormalities.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Auscultation: S1 and S2 heart sounds normal. Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops (S3, S4), or pericardial rubs. No carotid bruits.

ENT_Examination.Nasal_Cavity: Nasal mucosa appears pale and slightly boggy bilaterally. No polyps visualized. Septum midline. No active discharge.

Chest_X_Ray_PA_and_Lateral.Findings: Lungs are clear of any focal consolidation, effusion, or pneumothorax. Cardiomediastinal silhouette is within normal limits. Mild hyperinflation noted. No acute bony abnormalities.

Spirometry.Post_Bronchodilator_Salbutamol_400mcg: FEV1: 2.20 L (80% of predicted - an increase of 400mL and 22% from baseline), FVC: 3.10 L (88% of predicted), FEV1/FVC ratio: 0.71

Patient_Actor.History: The patient's mother reports a 3-day history of increasing nasal congestion and an intermittent dry cough. Over the past 24 hours, she noticed her daughter's breathing became faster, and she seems to be 'working a bit harder to breathe,' particularly during feeds. Oral intake has decreased by approximately 25% in the last day. The baby has been mildly fussy and more sleepy than usual. No high fevers were reported at home, although she felt 'warm to touch' on one occasion. An older sibling (4 years old) had a coryzal illness with a cough a week ago but has since recovered. Mother also mentions observing a faint, non-itchy red rash on the baby's trunk two days ago, which has now faded. The dyspnoea has been gradually worsening.

Respiratory_Examination.Palpation: Trachea central. Tactile fremitus normal.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Air entry good bilaterally. Few fine bibasilar crackles heard, which partially clear with coughing. No wheezes or rhonchi.

Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Soft, non-tender throughout all quadrants. No guarding or rebound tenderness. No palpable organomegaly.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient is a 68-year-old female who presents with an acute episode of dyspnoea that started approximately 3 hours ago while she was resting. She describes it as a 'suffocating feeling' and 'difficulty catching her breath.' This was accompanied by a sense of 'unease' and a vague, intermittent 'fluttering' in her chest, which she has noticed on and off for a few weeks but dismissed. She reports a background of progressively worsening exertional dyspnoea and significant fatigue over the past 6-8 months, which she attributed to 'getting older' and recent weight gain of 5kg. She can now only walk half a block before feeling breathless, compared to 2-3 blocks a year ago. She has noticed her ankles are slightly puffy in the evenings for the last month. She denies any specific chest pain, pressure, or tightness. No cough, wheezing, or sputum production. No fever or chills. She denies syncope but felt lightheaded during the acute episode. She has not had similar severe episodes before. Her last meal was normal. No recent travel or immobilization. She has been drinking more coffee lately to combat fatigue.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Sudden worsening of shortness of breath and a feeling of unease
Secondary_Symptoms: Long-standing fatigue and exertional dyspnoea for several months
Mild bilateral ankle swelling for one month

A small circumferential pericardial effusion (approximately 0.5 cm in maximum width) is noted. The intimal flap of an aortic dissection was not definitively visualized in the ascending aorta, though views were suboptimal in this region. Recommend urgent CT angiography for further evaluation of the aorta given dilated root, aortic regurgitation, pericardial effusion and clinical suspicion.

CT_Angiogram_Chest_Abdomen_Pelvis.Findings: Stanford Type A aortic dissection identified. An intimal flap originates just superior to the aortic valve sinuses, extending throughout the ascending aorta, into the aortic arch (sparing the origins of the arch vessels), and down the descending thoracic aorta to the level of the renal arteries. The false lumen shows partial thrombosis. A moderate-sized left pleural effusion and a small pericardial effusion are confirmed. No clear evidence of visceral or limb malperfusion at the time of scan. The true lumen is compressed in segments of the descending aorta.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Cardiovascular: dissecting aneurysm (Stanford Type A)

She denies any chest pain or discomfort. She has not experienced fevers, chills, or night sweats. No recent travel or known sick contacts.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Dyspnoea, worsening over time with more acute exacerbations recently

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypertension diagnosed 5 years ago, prescribed Lisinopril but admits to intermittent compliance. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 2 years ago, managed with Metformin. No history of ischemic heart disease, myocardial infarction, known valvular heart disease, asthma, or COPD. No previous cardiac interventions. Denies history of rheumatic fever or thyroid disease.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Retired school teacher. Consumes 1-2 glasses of wine per week. Ex-smoker, quit 20 years ago (10 pack-year history). Denies illicit drug use. Lives with her husband.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Lisinopril 10mg once daily (intermittent use). Metformin 500mg twice daily. Occasional paracetamol for headaches.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, pressure, or typical palpitations, though reports occasional 'skipped beats'. Reports mild bilateral ankle swelling, worse at day's end, attributing it to prolonged standing in the past. Respiratory: Confirms exertional dyspnoea and nocturnal cough. Denies wheezing or hemoptysis. Gastrointestinal: Appetite fair. Denies nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or change in bowel habits. Neurological: Reports occasional lightheadedness with postural changes. Denies syncope, focal weakness, or sensory changes. Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain or significant muscle aches. General: Reports significant fatigue. Denies fever or unexplained weight loss.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert, oriented. Appears mildly anxious and tachypnoeic at rest. No central or peripheral cyanosis. Not using accessory muscles prominently at rest.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Inspection: Jugular venous pressure not elevated at 45 degrees. No visible precordial bulge.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Palpation: Apex beat palpated in the 5th intercostal space, at the mid-clavicular line, normal character. No heaves or thrills.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Auscultation: S1 and S2 heart sounds present. A soft S3 gallop heard at the apex. No significant murmurs, rubs.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Symmetrical chest expansion. Mild intercostal recession noted with deeper breaths.
Respiratory_Examination.Palpation: Tactile fremitus normal bilaterally.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Fine bibasilar crackles heard, not clearing with cough. No wheezes or rhonchi.

Abdominal_Examination.Inspection: Abdomen is flat, non-distended. No visible scars.
Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Soft, non-tender. No hepatosplenomegaly.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Extremities_Examination: Trace bilateral pitting oedema up to the ankles. Peripheral pulses (radial, dorsalis pedis) are 2+ and equal bilaterally. No clubbing or cyanosis.

ECG.Findings: Sinus tachycardia at 96 bpm. Left ventricular hypertrophy by voltage criteria (Sokolow-Lyon). Non-specific T-wave flattening in leads V4-V6. No acute ST-T wave changes suggestive of ischemia. PR interval normal, QRS duration normal.

Chest_X_Ray.Findings: PA and Lateral views. Mild cardiomegaly (cardiothoracic ratio approx 0.55). Evidence of mild pulmonary venous congestion with cephalization of pulmonary vessels. Small bilateral pleural effusions, more prominent at the bases. No focal consolidation or pneumothorax.

Pulmonary_Function_Tests.Interpretation: Mild restrictive pattern, possibly related to pulmonary congestion or poor effort. No significant obstructive defect.

Echocardiogram.Findings: Moderately dilated left ventricle (LVEDD 6.2 cm, LVEDV Index 85 mL/m²). Global hypokinesis with severely reduced left ventricular ejection fraction, estimated at 30%. Grade I diastolic dysfunction. Mild functional mitral regurgitation. Mild functional tricuspid regurgitation. Right ventricular size and systolic function are at the lower limits of normal. Inferior vena cava normal diameter with >50% collapse on inspiration. No significant valvular stenosis. No pericardial effusion.

Cardiac_MRI.Findings: Ordered for further etiological assessment. Confirms dilated left ventricle with severely impaired systolic function (LVEF 28% by planimetry). Late gadolinium enhancement demonstrates patchy mid-myocardial striae in the interventricular septum and inferolateral wall, in a non-ischemic distribution. No evidence of significant myocardial oedema. No significant perfusion defects to suggest inducible ischemia. Findings consistent with a non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, potentially related to hypertensive heart disease or idiopathic dilated cardiomyopathy.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Cardiovascular: Cardiomyopathy (Dilated Cardiomyopathy, Non-ischemic)

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 1-week history of acutely worsening shortness of breath, now occurring with minimal exertion and sometimes at rest. No rigors or night sweats. Reports unintentional weight loss of approximately 1-2 kg over the past month, which he attributes to decreased appetite. Denies rashes, joint pains, recent travel, or sick contacts with prolonged respiratory illness. No palpitations. No urinary symptoms. No recent trauma.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert, appears tired and mildly dyspnoeic at rest. Using accessory muscles minimally for respiration.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Symmetrical chest expansion, no visible deformities or scars.
Respiratory_Examination.Palpation: Trachea central, normal tactile fremitus.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Fine bibasilar crackles heard, more prominent at end-inspiration. No wheezes, rhonchi, or pleural rub.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Heart sounds S1 and S2 normal, regular rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or pericardial rub. Jugular venous pressure not elevated. No peripheral edema.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly. Bowel sounds present.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Other: No clubbing or cyanosis. No palpable lymphadenopathy. Skin clear.

Microbiology.Sputum_Microscopy_Culture_Sensitivity: Few white blood cells, no organisms seen on Gram stain. Culture negative for bacterial pathogens after 48 hours. No acid-fast bacilli seen.
Microbiology.Viral_Respiratory_Panel_PCR: Negative for common respiratory viruses including Influenza A/B, RSV, Adenovirus, Parainfluenza, Metapneumovirus, Coronavirus (seasonal types).

Chest_X_Ray_PA_Lateral.Findings: Bilateral hazy interstitial opacities, predominantly in the mid and lower lung zones. No definite consolidation or large pleural effusion. Heart size within normal limits. Findings are non-specific, could represent atypical infection or inflammatory process.

CT_Chest_High_Resolution_HRCT.Findings: Extensive bilateral ground-glass opacities with superimposed patchy areas of consolidation, distributed somewhat asymmetrically but with a tendency towards the dependent portions of the lungs and lower lobes. No evidence of honeycombing or significant traction bronchiectasis. Mild interlobular septal thickening in affected areas. No significant mediastinal or hilar lymphadenopathy. No pleural effusions. Findings are consistent with an acute to subacute pneumonitis. No features of pulmonary embolism on the non-contrast HRCT portion visualized.

Other_Tests.ECG: Sinus rhythm, rate 98 bpm. No acute ischemic changes. Normal intervals and axis.
Other_Tests.Pulmonary_Function_Tests_deferred_due_to: Planned for follow-up if clinically indicated post-acute phase.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Chemical pneumonitis (secondary to inhalational exposure from furniture restoration products)

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 4-day history of worsening shortness of breath. She mentions he had a minor tumble from his toddler bed two days ago but seemed unhurt and behaved normally afterwards. Retropharyngeal space appears within upper normal limits for positioning. No definite radiopaque foreign body identified.

Examination revealed a markedly swollen, erythematous, 'cherry-red' epiglottis, with associated inflammation and edema of the aryepiglottic folds and arytenoids, consistent with acute epiglottitis. Cultures taken from epiglottic surface.

Other_Negative_Tests.Viral_Panel_Nasopharyngeal_Swab: Negative for Influenza A/B, RSV, Adenovirus, Parainfluenza viruses.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Infection: acute epiglottitis (children) due to Streptococcus pneumoniae

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Obesity (leading to restrictive lung physiology and obesity hypoventilation features)

Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain, palpitations, orthopnoea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea, or significant peripheral edema. Dermatological: Denies rashes or skin changes. Neurological: Denies headache, dizziness, focal weakness.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert and oriented. Appears mildly anxious and in mild respiratory distress, using accessory muscles of respiration. Not cyanotic. No clubbing.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Symmetrical chest movement, though right-sided expansion may be slightly reduced. Use of accessory muscles noted.
Respiratory_Examination.Palpation: Trachea central. Tactile fremitus reduced over the right upper and mid zones.
Respiratory_Examination.Percussion: Resonant throughout most lung fields, perhaps slightly impaired resonance over the right upper zone.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Decreased air entry over the right upper and mid lung zones. Fine late-inspiratory crackles heard over the right mid and upper lung zones posteriorly and anteriorly. No wheezes or rhonchi. No pleural rub.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Palpation: Apical impulse not displaced. No heaves or thrills.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Auscultation: S1 and S2 heart sounds normal. Regular tachycardia. No murmurs, gallops, or pericardial friction rub.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly. Bowel sounds present.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Lymph_Nodes: No palpable cervical, supraclavicular, or axillary lymphadenopathy.

Chest_X_Ray_PA_and_Lateral.Findings: Patchy, ill-defined opacities in the right upper and mid lung zones, consistent with previous radiation field. Mild loss of volume in the right upper lobe. Heart size normal. No large pleural effusion. Findings could represent post-radiation changes, infection, or other processes.

CT_Chest_with_IV_contrast_PE_protocol_an.Findings: Extensive ground-glass opacification and areas of consolidation are noted within the previously irradiated volume of the right lung, particularly the right upper lobe and superior segment of the right lower lobe. Associated features include interlobular septal thickening and early traction bronchiectasis within these areas, suggestive of radiation pneumonitis with developing fibrosis. No evidence of pulmonary embolism on the angiographic phase. No definite features of tumor recurrence; previously noted mediastinal lymph nodes are stable in size. Small right-sided pleural effusion. The left lung is clear.

Pulmonary_Function_Tests.Spirometry: FVC 2.10L (60% predicted), FEV1 1.80L (65% predicted), FEV1/FVC ratio 85%.

Echocardiogram.Findings: Left ventricular ejection fraction estimated at 60%. Normal left ventricular size and systolic function. Mild diastolic dysfunction (Grade 1). Right ventricle normal size and function. Estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure (PASP) 30 mmHg. No significant valvular abnormalities. No pericardial effusion.

Bronchoscopy_with_Bronchoalveolar_Lavage.Procedure_Note: Bronchoscopy performed to evaluate right lung opacities and rule out infection or malignancy. Airway inspection normal to the subsegmental level. BAL performed from the right upper lobe anterior segment.

BAL_Fluid_Analysis.Cell_Count_and_Differential: Total nucleated cells moderately increased. Differential: Macrophages 50%, Lymphocytes 40% (CD4/CD8 ratio normal), Neutrophils 8%, Eosinophils 2%.
BAL_Fluid_Analysis.Microbiology: Gram stain negative. Bacterial, fungal, and AFB cultures pending (subsequently negative). Viral PCR panel for common respiratory viruses negative.
BAL_Fluid_Analysis.Cytology: Negative for malignant cells. Numerous reactive pneumocytes and alveolar macrophages identified.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Radiation Pneumonitis with early Radiation Fibrosis

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 3-day history of rapidly worsening shortness of breath. She reports a baseline of mild exertional dyspnoea for the past year, which she attributed to being 'out of shape' (able to climb one flight of stairs before pausing). However, over the last 72 hours, her breathing has become difficult even at rest. This was preceded by a flu-like episode about 10 days ago with subjective fever, myalgia, and fatigue, which seemed to resolve after a few days. A dry, persistent cough started concurrently with the acute worsening of dyspnoea. She denies any specific chest pain, but feels a general tightness. She denies orthopnoea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. She also denies any recent travel, surgery, or prolonged immobility.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Acute worsening of dyspnoea over 3 days, on a background of mild chronic exertional dyspnoea
Secondary_Symptoms: Sensation of chest tightness (non-pleuritic, non-exertional pain)

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hospitalized 4 weeks ago for acute pancreatitis (gallstone-related, cholecystectomy planned electively, resolved with conservative management, discharged after 5 days). Otherwise, generally healthy. No known cardiac disease. No history of asthma or COPD. Vaccinations up to date. No known drug allergies.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Non-smoker. Drinks 2-3 glasses of wine per week. Works as a primary school teacher. Lives with her husband and two children.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: No palpitations, syncope, or dizziness. No hemoptysis or purulent sputum. No leg swelling or pain. No current abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. Bowels regular. No urinary symptoms. No rashes or joint pains. No night sweats beyond the febrile episode 10 days ago. No recent unexplained weight loss. Denies any new medications.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert but anxious female, visibly dyspnoeic, using accessory muscles of respiration. Appears pale.

Respiratory_Examination.Percussion: Resonant to percussion throughout both lung fields.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Bilateral fine inspiratory crackles heard throughout mid and lower lung zones. No wheezes or rhonchi. No pleural rub.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Palpation: Apex beat not displaced, normal character.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Auscultation: S1 and S2 heart sounds normal, no murmurs, gallops or rubs. Tachycardia noted.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Peripheral: No peripheral edema. Capillary refill time 2 seconds. Pulses palpable and symmetrical.

Abdominal_Examination.Inspection: Abdomen flat, no scars.
Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Soft, non-tender. No hepatosplenomegaly.

Neurological_Examination.Mental_Status: Alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Appears anxious.
Neurological_Examination.Motor_System: Normal power and tone in all four limbs.

Microbiology.Sputum_Culture_Gram_Stain: Scant epithelial cells, mixed oral flora, no predominant pathogen seen on Gram stain. Culture pending.
Microbiology.Viral_Respiratory_Panel (NPA swab): Negative for Influenza A/B, RSV, SARS-CoV-2, and other common respiratory viruses.

ECG.Findings: Sinus tachycardia at 110 bpm. Normal axis. No ST segment elevation or depression. No T wave inversion. PR and QTc intervals normal. No features of right heart strain.

Chest_XRay (Portable, AP view).Findings: Bilateral diffuse hazy opacities, more prominent in the mid and lower lung zones, with some air bronchograms. Heart size is normal. No large pleural effusions. Pulmonary vasculature appears normal.

CT_Chest_Angiogram_Lung_Windows.Findings: No evidence of pulmonary embolism. Extensive bilateral ground-glass opacities and areas of consolidation, predominantly in dependent lung regions, with interlobular septal thickening. No significant pleural effusions. Normal cardiac chamber sizes. Findings are consistent with diffuse alveolar damage.

Echocardiogram (Transthoracic).Findings: Left ventricular ejection fraction estimated at 60%. Normal left ventricular size and wall thickness. No regional wall motion abnormalities. Mild Grade I diastolic dysfunction. Right ventricular size and systolic function normal. No significant valvular abnormalities. No pericardial effusion. Estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure 30 mmHg (within normal limits). Overall, no clear echocardiographic explanation for acute pulmonary edema.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), likely secondary to recent pancreatitis

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy 2 weeks ago. Hypertension, well-controlled on medication. Hyperlipidemia. No history of asthma, COPD, or heart failure. No previous DVT/PE.

Abdominal_Examination.Palpation: Soft, non-tender. No organomegaly.

Electrocardiogram_ECG.ST_T_changes: No acute ST segment elevation or depression. No T wave inversion suggestive of ischemia.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 4-month history of a persistent, nagging cough, which was initially dry but has recently become productive of yellowish sputum. Over the past three days, he developed an acute worsening of his cough, accompanied by audible wheezing, shortness of breath, especially on exertion, and a fever reported up to 38.5°C at home. His parents report he has had two episodes of 'chest infections' in the past 3 months, treated with amoxicillin by their GP, with only temporary and partial improvement each time. His mother vaguely recalls an episode about 4-5 months ago where he had a sudden coughing and choking fit while eating peanuts at his grandparents' house; he seemed to recover quickly, so it wasn't pursued further. She is uncertain about the exact timing and details of this event. He has been less willing to engage in active play recently due to breathlessness.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Chronic cough with acute worsening of shortness of breath and wheeze

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Two episodes diagnosed as 'chest infection' or 'bronchitis' in the last 3 months, treated with oral antibiotics. No history of diagnosed asthma, eczema, or allergic rhinitis. No previous hospitalizations or surgeries. Vaccinations are up to date.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Lives with parents and an older sibling in a house. No smokers in the household. No pets. Attends kindergarten. No known exposure to tuberculosis. Parents deny any significant dust or mold exposure at home. Child has access to small toys and sometimes eats nuts under supervision.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Amoxicillin for recent 'chest infections'. No regular medications. No known drug allergies.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: General: Reports fatigue and irritability during acute episodes. Denies significant weight loss. Respiratory: As per HPI. Denies hemoptysis. Denies chest pain unrelated to coughing spells. Cardiovascular: Denies palpitations, syncope, peripheral edema. Gastrointestinal: Appetite generally good between acute episodes, slightly reduced currently. Denies vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, or symptoms suggestive of reflux. ENT: Denies chronic rhinorrhea, post-nasal drip, recurrent sinusitis, or current sore throat. Dermatological: No rashes, no history of eczema. Musculoskeletal: No joint pains or swelling.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert, appears uncomfortable and mildly dyspneic. Audible expiratory wheeze.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Mild subcostal and intercostal retractions. Chest expansion appears subtly reduced on the right side.
Respiratory_Examination.Palpation: Trachea is midline. Tactile fremitus slightly decreased over the right mid and lower lung fields.
Respiratory_Examination.Percussion: Slightly dull note over the right middle and lower zones posteriorly and laterally. Left lung resonant throughout.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Decreased air entry over the right middle and lower lung zones. A persistent, localized monophonic wheeze is noted in the right mid-zone, predominantly on expiration. Few scattered coarse crackles in the right mid and lower zones. Left lung fields are clear with good air entry. No stridor.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Regular tachycardia. S1 and S2 heart sounds normal. No murmurs or gallops.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly. Bowel sounds present and normal.
Physical_Examination_Findings.ENT_Examination: Oropharynx clear, no tonsillar exudate or erythema. Tympanic membranes normal bilaterally. No nasal discharge.

Microbiology.Sputum_Culture: Streptococcus pneumoniae isolated, sensitive to penicillin. Mixed upper respiratory flora also present.

Pulmonary_Function_Tests.Spirometry_Attempt: Attempted, but limited cooperation due to age and acute symptoms. Recorded FEV1/FVC ratio was 0.65, suggesting an obstructive pattern, but full curves not reliably obtained. Minimal change post-bronchodilator (salbutamol nebulization).

Chest_X_Ray_PA_Lateral_Initial.Findings: Patchy opacification in the right middle lobe with associated subtle volume loss, consistent with consolidation and atelectasis. Right hilum appears unremarkable. Left lung is clear. No definite foreign body visualized. Cardiomediastinal silhouette is normal. No pleural effusion.

Chest_X_Ray_PA_Lateral_Follow_up_post_an.Findings: Persistent opacification and atelectasis in the right middle lobe, with only slight interval improvement in the consolidative changes compared to previous study 7 days ago. Continued subtle hyperinflation of the right lower lobe.

CT_Chest_with_IV_contrast.Findings: A small, ovoid, low-attenuation endobronchial lesion, measuring approximately 5mm x 3mm, is identified within the bronchus intermedius on the right. This is associated with significant atelectasis and post-obstructive pneumonitis of the right middle lobe. There is also mild compensatory hyperinflation of the right lower lobe. No other focal lung lesions. Mediastinal structures unremarkable. No significant lymphadenopathy.

Other_Investigations.Allergy_Testing_Skin_Prick: Negative for common aeroallergens (dust mite, grass pollen, cat, dog dander).
Other_Investigations.ECG: Sinus tachycardia at 120 bpm. Normal axis. No signs of right ventricular hypertrophy or strain.

Flexible_Bronchoscopy.Findings: Performed under general anesthesia. Edema and inflammation noted in the right main bronchus extending into the bronchus intermedius. A tan-colored, firm foreign body, consistent in appearance with a fragment of a peanut shell, was visualized partially occluding the orifice of the right middle lobe bronchus and extending into the bronchus intermedius. The foreign body was successfully removed using forceps. Surrounding mucosa was erythematous and friable. Bronchoalveolar lavage sent for culture showed mixed flora.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Inhaled foreign body (peanut fragment) in right bronchus intermedius, complicated by recurrent right middle lobe pneumonia and atelectasis

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with progressively worsening shortness of breath over the past six months, which has become significantly more pronounced in the last two weeks. Initially, dyspnoea occurred only with strenuous activity, but now he experiences it with minimal exertion, such as walking around his home, and occasionally at rest. He also reports a persistent, dry cough, particularly troublesome at night and when lying supine. He describes a vague, intermittent right-sided chest discomfort as a dull ache or pressure, not sharp or pleuritic. He has noted an unintentional weight loss of approximately 3 kg over the last four months and complains of general fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance. He mentions a history of what his GP termed 'recurrent chest infections' over the past year, treated with oral antibiotics, with only partial and temporary improvement in his respiratory symptoms after each course.

Secondary_Symptoms: Persistent dry cough, worse supine and at night
Vague, intermittent right-sided chest discomfort (dull ache/pressure)
Unintentional weight loss (3 kg over 4 months)
Mild bilateral ankle swelling in evenings for 1 month

No known history of heart failure, coronary artery disease, asthma, COPD, or malignancy. No previous thoracic surgery or significant chest trauma. No known tuberculosis exposure.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a 3-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath, initially only on significant exertion like climbing several flights of stairs, but has acutely worsened over the last 72 hours, now experiencing dyspnoea with minimal activity like walking around his apartment. He also reports a persistent, mostly dry cough for the past 2-3 months, which has recently become occasionally productive of small amounts of whitish sputum. He notes unintentional weight loss of approximately 4 kg over the last 3 months, which he attributed to stress and poor appetite. He mentions feeling fatigued and generally unwell during this period. He sometimes feels 'warm' at night but hasn't formally checked his temperature and denies drenching night sweats. He initially thought he had a lingering cold or 'bronchitis'.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Progressive dyspnoea, acutely worsened
Secondary_Symptoms: Persistent cough, recently slightly productive (whitish sputum)

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: History of 'recurrent chest infections' in the past year, treated with oral antibiotics with transient improvement. No history of asthma beyond childhood (mild, infrequent symptoms, no current treatment). No known cardiac disease, diabetes, or immunosuppressive conditions. No previous surgeries. States he had a 'shadow on the lung' noted on a chest X-ray during a pre-employment medical check 10 years ago in his home country, but was told it was 'old scarring' and received no treatment or further follow-up.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as an office cleaner. Immigrated from Southeast Asia 18 months ago. Former smoker, quit 5 years ago (5 pack-year history). Drinks alcohol socially (1-2 beers per week). Lives with his wife and two children in an apartment. Denies illicit drug use. Initially hesitant to provide full immigration history.
Patient_Actor.Medications: No regular medications. Occasionally uses over-the-counter cough syrup.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Confirms progressive dyspnoea and cough. Denies frank hemoptysis, chest pain, palpitations, orthopnoea, or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnoea. Denies significant wheezing. Appetite is reduced. No headaches, visual changes, joint pain, skin rashes, or abdominal pain. Bowel habits normal. Denies urinary symptoms. No known recent contact with individuals with persistent cough or diagnosed tuberculosis.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Thin male, appears tired and mildly dyspnoeic at rest. Alert and cooperative.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Symmetrical chest expansion. No use of accessory muscles at rest. No visible scars or deformities.
Respiratory_Examination.Palpation: Trachea midline. Tactile fremitus slightly increased over the right upper chest. No palpable crepitus.
Respiratory_Examination.Percussion: Dullness to percussion over the right apex. Elsewhere resonant.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Reduced air entry in the right upper zone. Fine crackles heard over the right apex, more prominent after coughing. No wheezes or pleural rub heard. Bronchial breath sounds appreciated over a small area in the right infraclavicular region.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Cardiovascular_Examination: Tachycardia, regular rhythm. S1 and S2 normal. No murmurs, gallops, or pericardial rub. Jugular Venous Pressure not elevated. No peripheral edema.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender. No hepatosplenomegaly. Bowel sounds normal.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Lymph_Nodes: No palpable cervical, supraclavicular, or axillary lymphadenopathy.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Other: No clubbing of fingers. Skin examination unremarkable.

Sputum_Analysis.Gram_Stain_and_Culture: Mixed oral flora, no predominant pathogen. No growth of typical bacterial pathogens after 48 hours.
Sputum_Analysis.AFB_Smear (x3 samples): Negative for Acid-Fast Bacilli on all three samples.

Chest_X_ray (PA_and_Lateral).Findings: Infiltrate and consolidation in the right upper lobe with evidence of a small (2 cm) cavitary lesion. Some fibrotic stranding noted. No significant pleural effusion. Cardiomediastinal silhouette within normal limits. Left lung clear.

CT_Chest_High_Resolution (ordered due to.Findings: Confirms a 2.2 cm thick-walled cavity in the apical segment of the right upper lobe. Surrounding parenchymal consolidation with associated tree-in-bud opacities and small centrilobular nodules in adjacent segments of the RUL. Minor right paratracheal lymph node noted, 8mm short axis. No significant pleural effusion. Left lung clear. Findings highly suggestive of active post-primary tuberculosis.

Other_Tests.ECG: Sinus tachycardia at 105 bpm. No acute ST-T wave changes. Normal axis and intervals.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Pulmonary Tuberculosis (smear-negative, GeneXpert positive)

Patient_Actor.History: The patient presents with a progressive history of dyspnoea. Over the past year, she reports 'getting breathless more easily' with activities like climbing stairs or brisk walking, which she initially attributed to 'getting older and putting on a bit of weight.' She also notes her voice has been 'a bit weaker' and occasionally 'raspy,' especially if she talks for extended periods. For the past three weeks, following a mild sore throat and rhinorrhoea (which resolved within a few days), her breathing difficulty has significantly worsened. She now experiences shortness of breath with minimal exertion and sometimes at rest. She describes her breathing as 'louder' or 'noisy,' particularly when lying down at night, and reports several episodes of waking up suddenly feeling like she 'can't catch her breath,' causing considerable anxiety. She denies any frank wheezing episodes similar to asthma attacks.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Progressive shortness of breath, with recent acute worsening
Secondary_Symptoms: Episodes of waking from sleep with severe dyspnoea

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Hypothyroidism, diagnosed 15 years ago, well-controlled on levothyroxine. Hypertension, diagnosed 5 years ago, controlled with amlodipine. Diagnosed with 'mild asthma' 10 years ago, prescribed a salbutamol inhaler which she uses very infrequently (less than once a month) stating it 'doesn't seem to do much.' No history of neck surgery or trauma. No known allergies to medications.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Levothyroxine 75mcg daily, Amlodipine 5mg daily, Salbutamol inhaler (rarely used).
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Works as a part-time librarian. Non-smoker, never smoked. Drinks 2-3 glasses of wine per week. Lives with her husband. Denies illicit drug use.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies chest pain, palpitations, orthopnoea requiring multiple pillows (though prefers sleeping on one side), or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea that resolves with sitting up (describes waking gasping). No cough productive of sputum, no fever or chills. No peripheral edema or weight gain. Appetite normal. No dysphagia or odynophagia. No recent travel. No unusual occupational exposures. Denies symptoms of GERD. Denies hemoptysis, night sweats, or unintentional weight loss. No skin rashes or joint pains.

Vital_Signs.Respiratory_Rate: 20 breaths/min (appears comfortable at rest but breathing is audible)

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert, oriented, and cooperative. Appears mildly anxious. Not in acute respiratory distress at rest during conversation, but speech is somewhat soft and slightly breathy. No cyanosis or pallor.

HEENT_Examination.Neck: Supple. No palpable lymphadenopathy. Thyroid gland not enlarged or tender. Trachea midline. No visible masses or scars. Carotid pulses normal.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Symmetrical chest expansion. Mild use of accessory muscles of neck observed during deeper inspiration. No obvious deformity.
Respiratory_Examination.Palpation: Chest expansion good and symmetrical. No tactile fremitus abnormalities.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Air entry good bilaterally. Vesicular breath sounds. No wheezes, crackles, or rhonchi heard over lung parenchyma. On forced deep inspiration, a soft, high-pitched inspiratory sound (stridor) is faintly audible when listening over the larynx/upper trachea. Expiratory phase is not prolonged.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Heart_Sounds: S1 and S2 normal. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender. No organomegaly. Bowel sounds normal.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Neurological_Examination: Grossly intact. Cranial nerves II-XII grossly normal (voice quality noted as above). Motor strength and sensation normal in all limbs.

Blood_Tests.Brain_Natriuretic_Peptide: 45 pg/mL (Normal, makes heart failure less likely)

ECG.Findings: Sinus rhythm, rate 85 bpm. Normal axis. No acute ST-T wave changes. No signs of ischemia or right heart strain. (Negative for acute cardiac cause of dyspnoea)

Chest_XRay_PA_Lateral.Findings: Lungs are clear bilaterally with no focal consolidation, effusion, or pneumothorax. Cardiomediastinal silhouette is within normal limits. Trachea appears midline and its caliber within normal limits on AP view, though assessment is limited. (Negative for common pulmonary and cardiac causes of dyspnoea; non-diagnostic for upper airway pathology)

CT_Neck_with_Contrast.Findings: The thyroid gland is normal in size and appearance. No extrinsic mass lesion identified compressing the trachea or larynx. The visualized portions of the lungs apices are clear. Subtle finding of both vocal cords in a paramedian position during the scan, resulting in a somewhat narrowed glottic aperture. No definite causative lesion for this positioning identified on CT. (Suggestive of vocal cord dysfunction, but not definitive for cause; rules out large mass)

Spirometry_Flow_Volume_Loop.Inspiratory_Loop_Pattern: Marked flattening of the inspiratory limb of the flow-volume loop, with significantly reduced Peak Inspiratory Flow Rate (PIFR < 50% predicted). Expiratory loop shape relatively preserved. (Highly suggestive of variable extrathoracic upper airway obstruction)
Spirometry_Flow_Volume_Loop.Bronchodilator_Response: No significant change in FEV1 or FVC post-bronchodilator. (Negative for significant reversible airflow obstruction typical of asthma)

Flexible_Nasendoscopy_Laryngoscopy.Findings: Direct visualization of the larynx revealed both vocal cords positioned in the paramedian position. During inspiration, there was minimal to no abduction of either vocal cord. The posterior glottic chink was estimated to be approximately 3-4 mm at its widest. Vocal cord adduction during phonation was normal. Mucosa appeared healthy with no lesions, edema, or signs of inflammation. (Confirms bilateral vocal cord abductor paralysis; negative for tumor, edema or inflammation as cause of obstruction)

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Upper Airway Obstruction secondary to Bilateral Vocal Cord Abductor Paralysis (idiopathic or post-viral)

Patient_Actor.History: The patient reports a 6-month history of intermittent, mild shortness of breath, particularly with moderate exertion, which he attributed to being 'out of shape' and his smoking habit. Over the past 24 hours, following an episode of forceful coughing yesterday evening, his shortness of breath has acutely worsened and is now present even at rest. He also describes a persistent, vague discomfort on the right side of his chest, more like a 'pressure' or 'tightness' rather than a sharp, stabbing pain. He feels generally fatigued.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Acute worsening of chronic dyspnoea
Secondary_Symptoms: Occasional dry cough (pre-existing, attributed to smoking)

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: No diagnosed chronic illnesses. History of seasonal allergies. Wisdom teeth extraction 5 years ago. No history of asthma or known lung disease.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Smoker, approximately 10 cigarettes per day for 10 years (10 pack-years). Drinks 2-3 beers on weekends. Works as a barista. Denies illicit drug use. Lives alone.
Patient_Actor.Medications: Occasional antihistamines for allergies. No regular medications.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies fever, chills, night sweats. No significant weight loss recently. Denies palpitations, orthopnoea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or leg swelling. No hemoptysis. No sputum production beyond usual minimal morning smoker's cough. Denies nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain. Denies syncope or pre-syncope. No recent trauma to the chest. No recent long-distance travel or prolonged immobility. Denies symptoms of calf swelling or pain.

Physical_Examination_Findings.General_Appearance: Alert, appears mildly anxious and in some respiratory discomfort. Speaking in full sentences but takes breaths more frequently. Not cyanosed.

Respiratory_Examination.Inspection: Symmetrical chest movement on inspiration, perhaps slightly reduced overall expansion. No obvious use of accessory muscles at rest. No visible deformities or scars.
Respiratory_Examination.Palpation: Trachea is central. Chest expansion subjectively slightly diminished on the right side compared to the left on deep inspiration. No palpable tenderness or crepitus.
Respiratory_Examination.Percussion: Percussion note is slightly more resonant over the right upper anterior and lateral chest compared to the left. Elsewhere, resonant bilaterally.
Respiratory_Examination.Auscultation: Breath sounds are audibly diminished in the right upper and mid zones, particularly apically. No wheezes, crackles, or pleural rub heard. Normal vesicular breath sounds on the left.

Cardiovascular_Examination.Inspection_Palpation: Apex beat not displaced, normal character.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Auscultation: S1 and S2 heart sounds are normal. Regular tachycardia. No murmurs, gallops, or pericardial rub. Jugular Venous Pressure not elevated.
Cardiovascular_Examination.Peripheral_Pulses: All peripheral pulses palpable and symmetrical.

Physical_Examination_Findings.Abdominal_Examination: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly. Bowel sounds present.
Physical_Examination_Findings.Extremities: No peripheral edema, cyanosis, or clubbing. Calves soft and non-tender.

Blood_Tests.D_dimer: 480 ng/mL FEU (Upper limit of normal <500 ng/mL)

ECG.Intervals: PR, QRS, QTc within normal limits
ECG.ST_T_Changes: No acute ST segment elevation or depression. Non-specific T wave flattening in leads V1-V3. No features of right heart strain.

Chest_X_ray_PA_upright.Findings: Initial interpretation: Lungs appear generally well-aerated. Subtle lucency noted in the right apical region with a questionable thin line paralleling the chest wall, suspicious for a small visceral pleural edge. Lung markings appear to extend to the periphery elsewhere. No definite large pneumothorax, consolidation, or pleural effusion. Cardiac silhouette size is normal. Further evaluation with expiratory view or CT chest advised if clinically indicated for pneumothorax.

CT_Chest_non_contrast_high_resolution_pr.Findings: Confirms a right-sided pneumothorax, measuring approximately 2.5 cm at its largest dimension between the visceral pleura and chest wall in the apical and lateral regions (estimated 20-25% volume). Several small subpleural blebs, the largest measuring 0.8 cm, are noted at the right lung apex. No tension features. The contralateral lung is clear. No mediastinal shift. No pleural effusion or consolidation. Visualized pulmonary arteries are patent, no evidence of central pulmonary embolism on this non-contrast study.

OSCE_Examination.Correct_Diagnosis: Right-sided primary spontaneous pneumothorax (moderate)
